Theodorus of Cyrene
was a pupil of
Protagoras
and himself the tutor of
Plato
, teaching him mathematics, and also the tutor of
Theaetetus
.
Plato
travelled to and from Egypt and on such occasions he spent time with Theodorus in Cyrene. Theodorus, however, did not spend his whole life in Cyrene for he was certainly in Athens at a time when
Socrates
was alive.
Theodorus, in addition to his work in mathematics, was
[

... distinguished ... in astronomy, arithmetic, music and all educational subjects.
A member of the society of
Pythagoras
, Theodorus was one of the main philosophers in the Cyrenaic school of moral philosophy. He believed that pleasures and pains are neither good nor bad. Cheerfulness and wisdom, he believed, were sufficient for happiness.
Our knowledge of Theodorus comes through
Plato
who wrote about him in his work
Theaetetus
. Theodorus is remembered by mathematicians for his contribution to the development of
irrational
numbers and it is this aspect of his work which
